## Overview

__Stringr__ is the main string manipulation package in __tidyverse__.

__Stringr__ focusses on the most important and comonly used string manipulation functions.
It is based on [stringi](https://github.com/gagolews/stringi) which has a comprehensive set of functions.

[stringr homepage](https://stringr.tidyverse.org/)

This website aims to quickly cover some of the `stringr` functions and uses.
Therefore, there are a lot more `stringr` functions than covered here.
Please check the below link for the full list.

[Full stringr reference page](https://stringr.tidyverse.org/reference/index.html)

If you are unfamiliar with strings please see:

[String chapter in R for Data Science 2e](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/strings)

### Character manipulation

<div class="hexrow">
  <p><a href="/stringr/str_length.qmd">
  <img src="images/stringr_str_length.png" width="150px">
  </a></p>

  <p><a href="/stringr/str_sub.qmd">
  <img src="images/stringr_str_sub.png" width="150px">
  </a></p>

  <p><a href="/stringr/str_dup.qmd">
  <img src="images/stringr_str_dup.png" width="150px">
  </a></p>

</div>

These functions allow you to manipulate strings in vectors.

- [`str_length()`](/stringr/str_length.qmd): Determine the length of a string (i.e. count the number of characters in a string).
- [`str_sub()`](/stringr/str_sub.qmd): Extract or modify a substring using a start and end position.
- [`str_dup()`](/stringr/str_dup.qmd): Duplicate a string a specified number of times.

### Combining strings

<div class="hexrow">
  <p><a href="/stringr/str_c.qmd">
  <img src="images/stringr_str_c.png" width="150px">
  </a></p>

  <p><a href="/stringr/str_flatten.qmd">
  <img src="images/stringr_str_flatten.png" width="150px">
  </a></p>

  <p><a href="/stringr/str_glue.qmd">
  <img src="images/stringr_str_glue.png" width="150px">
  </a></p>

</div>

- [`str_c()`](/stringr/str_c.qmd): Combine strings together (similar to `paste0()`).
- [`str_flatten()`](/stringr/str_flatten.qmd): Flatten a vector of strings into one string.
- [`str_glue()`](/stringr/str_glue.qmd): SImilar to `str_c()` but allows you to include variables within the strings to combine.
  - Variable names are included in the strings with curly braces like so: `{variable_name}`


### White space tools

These functions allow you to add, remove, and manipulate whitespaces (e.g. spaces and tabs)

### Pattern matching

These functions allow you to carry out various tasks with regular expressions.

For an introduction to regular expressions please see the [Regular expressions chapter in R for Data Science 2e](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/regexps.html)
